title: West Acre Walks

images.title: West Acre, Norfolk - Village sign & Priory Gateway by Colin Park, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption:
West Acre, Norfolk - Village sign & Priory Gateway. The gateway to the 13th-century Priory sits immediately to the west of All Saints Church. The church itself is rather striking, being essentially Perpendicular in style, which is a phase of Gothic architecture that emphasises vertical lines and large windows. Sir Edward Barkham substantially rebuilt the church in the 17th century, and his death head symbol is placed above the entrance to the porch, adding a unique historical touch. This porch contains a 13th-century relief sculpture, showcasing the church's long history and artistic heritage. The clock on the tower serves as a poignant reminder to "Watch and Pray," reflecting the spiritual focus of the church.
All Saints is one of seven churches that belong to the Nar Valley Group, a collection of parishes ministered by Canon Stuart Nairn. This grouping allows the communities to share resources and clergy, fostering a sense of unity and collaboration among the local churches.

images.title: Robert Walden / Farm track opposite Home Farm & West Acre Gardens
images.caption: Farm track opposite Home Farm and West Acre Gardens. West Acre Gardens are located in a lovely old walled garden. This nursery is a treasure trove for plant lovers and the extensive display gardens have year round interest and beauty.

images.title: The angel of the Norfolk by Richard Humphrey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The angel of the Norfolk

description: The pretty Norfolk village of West Acre lies just to the west of Castle Acre on the Nar Valley Way footpath. This walk from the village takes you east along the waymarked trail to visit the historic castle and ancient priory remains at neighbouring Castle Acre. Along the way there are some lovely views of the River Nar and the surrounding Norfolk countryside. There's also some picturesque fords and a noteworthy Grade I listed church to see in the village. Please scroll down for the full list of walks near and around West Acre. The detailed maps below also show a range of footpaths, bridleways and cycle paths in the area.
